conclusion: Determine the refractive index of the glass column using given geometry and conditions.
The glass column has a quarter circle cross-section with radius R.
The light beam enters at point P on the arc and travels parallel to the line AC.
The distance from point P to the line AC is (sqrt(3)R)/2.
The light exits at point M on the line BC, where MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3.
Find the coordinates of P using the distance from P to AC and the equation of the circle.
The light travels horizontally from P to BC, so the y-coordinate of M is the same as that of P.
MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3 implies M is (sqrt(3)R)/3 units above C, consistent with the y-coordinate (sqrt(3)R)/2.
The angle of incidence at BC is 90 degrees since the light travels horizontally.
Calculate the angle of refraction using the geometry of the triangle formed by B, C, and M.
The tangent of the angle of refraction is (sqrt(3)/3), so the angle of refraction is 30 degrees.
Using Snell's Law, calculate the refractive index: n = sin(30 degrees)/sin(90 degrees) = 1/2.
The refractive index of the glass column is 2.
